Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Focused Study of Aleutian Plutons and their Host Rocks: Understanding the building blocks of continental crust
Award.AbstractNarration:
Arc magmatism is the most important process that generates the continental crust today and likely throughout Earth's history. However, average continental crust composition is andesitic and calc-alkaline, while average arc lava composition is basaltic and tholeiitic. The largely unexposed and unsampled plutonic part of the arcs, on the other hand, may be more similar to the continental crust. Therefore, understanding the genesis of plutonic rocks is a key to understanding continental crust formation and evolution via arc magmatism, a key science goal for the GeoPRISMS initiative. The Aleutian arc is uniquely well-suited for such a study, because of the extensive exposures of plutonic rocks, unmatched in any other intra-oceanic arc. In the Aleutian arc, most felsic plutonic rocks have compositions that overlap estimates for the bulk continental crust. Our pilot study found that Eocene-Miocene plutonic rocks and Holocene volcanic rocks show distinctly different elemental and isotopic signatures, which indicate that they were derived from distinct parental magmas. This difference could reflect temporal variation of the mantle under the region, or fundamentally different mechanisms that form plutons and lavas - perhaps strongly calc-alkaline magmas, with high H2O contents, tend to degas in the mid-crust, causing a rapid increase in viscosity and crystallinity, therefore they tent to stall and form plutons; while hotter, drier, tholeiitic basalts have lower viscosity and readily erupt to form lavas.

As it is crucial to understand the extent and origin of the compositional difference between central Aleutian lavas and plutons through time and space, this project will map and sample plutonic rocks exposed on the central Aleutians and their coeval volcanic host rocks. A subset of the most promising samples will be measured for major element, trace element and isotopic compositions (Sr, Nd, Hf, Pb). The ages of the plutons and/or the lavas will be constrained using U-Pb zircon geochronology and 40Ar/39Ar geochronology analyses of plagioclase phenocrysts and the groundmass. These preliminary results and the samples acquired in this study will help to answer fundamental questions of continental crust formation, and shed light on the formation mechanisms of plutons and volcanics in arcs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arc magmatism is the most important process that generates continental crust today and probably throughout most of Earth history. It is commonly inferred that the composition of primitive arc lavas is representative of the bulk composition of arc crust. However, the composition of average arc lavas is basaltic with low Mg/Fe while the average continental crust is andesitic with high Mg/Fe. An important goal of igneous petrology is to resolve this apparent paradox and explain the role of arc magmatism in the genesis and evolution of continental crust.

We found in a pilot study (Cai et al., 2015) that central-eastern Aleutian plutonic rocks with ages from 9 Ma to 39 Ma show more "depleted" isotopic signatures, elevated Si and high Mg/Fe compared to Holocene volcanics from the same region. Based on this result, we proposed two hypotheses: 1) a temporal change in the Aleutian magma source, starting at about 10 Ma caused changes in magma composition or 2) plutonic rocks were derived from different parental magmas, with higher water and Si in the magmas than those that formed most erupted lavas.

This study aims to evaluate these two hypotheses.

Our results to date are as follows:

During the field campaign, we confirmed many earlier observations by USGS scientists and discovered many new sites of pillow lavas and sills. We collected over 500 high-quality samples, which encompass most of the plutonic formations on Unalaska, Umnak and Atka and many volcanic formations, including pillow lavas, cinders and lava flows.

  • Ages

New Ar-Ar and U-Pb zircon ages on a representative 20% of collected samples that include both volcanics and plutonics range from 3 to 54 Ma (Figure 1).

  • Isotopic data on older plutons and lavas

On adjacent Unalaska and Umnak Islands, isotope ratios in volcanics older than 10 Ma resemble coeval plutonic rocks (Figure 2). Both have a broad range of isotopic compositions, with εNd from 7 to 9.6 and 207Pb/204Pb ratios from 15.515 to 15.570.

In contrast, on Atka island, plutons and lavas have a similar range of εNd, but plutons record a magmatic source that is systematically depleted in 207Pb/204Pb compared to coeval lavas. 11 of 13 plutons have 207Pb/204Pb lower than 15.515, whereas six of eight lavas have 207Pb/204Pb higher than this. After eliminating an anomalous lava with the least radiogenic Pb among all our samples (ATK15-116), statistical T-tests reveal a < 2% chance that the pluton and lava 207Pb/204Pb data come from the same normally distributed population.

Combining new and published data, we find that plutonic rocks have higher average Si contents than volcanic rocks at a given Fe/Mg ratio (Figure 3) so that the plutonic rocks are more calc-alkaline and closer in composition to the average continental crust. On Atka, the plutons are isotopically distinct from the lavas, indicating that the two rock types formed from distinctly different parental magmas. On Unalaska and Umnak, the plutons and lavas have the same, broad range of isotope ratios. Thus, either (a) they formed via different crystallization processes from a common parental magma composition, or (b) they formed from compositionally different parental magmas with a similar range of isotope ratios.

  • Temporal evolution of isotope compositions

On Unalaska, Umnak and Atka, there is a clear temporal progression toward lower εNd after about 15 Ma, with the younger lavas completely overlapping the range in εNd among Holocene lavas (Figure 2). There is a hint of a similar progression among Unalaska + Umnak plutons, but no evident trend for Atka plutons.

On Unalaska + Umnak, Pb isotope ratios in all samples overlap the lower half of the range for Holocene volcanics compiled by Cai et al. (EPSL 2015). There are no 207Pb/204Pb ratios below 15.53 in samples younger than 10 Ma. These data suggest a wide range of parental magma compositions, with variable isotope ratios for plutons and lavas, with both gradually becoming more isotopically enriched after ~ 10 Ma.

On Atka, the one pluton younger than 10 Ma has a low 207Pb/204Pb of 15.50, while the two lavas ≤ 10 Ma have higher 207Pb/204Pb of 15.520 and 15.529. Atka lavas may record a temporal trend of increasing Pb isotope ratios. All five lavas older than 12 Ma have 207Pb/204Pb less than 15.528, while all three lavas younger than 12 Ma have 207Pb/204Pb from 15.539 to 15.547. However, all of these are still lower than the lower end of the Holocene lava range, from 15.550 to 15.620. The lava data might indicate an increasingly abundant sediment component in the source of Atka lavas after 12 Ma. However, other processes, such as changes in subduction parameters or the source of the sediments (e.g., subducting isotopically more "enriched” sediments sourced from older continental crust) can also generate this type of shift in magma compositions. There is no corresponding temporal trend in 207Pb/204Pb  for Atka plutons.
